claims.text: Woolworths stores stopped accepting cash on May 26.

claimReview.title: Cashless supermarket claim has no currency
claimReview.textualRating: False. Cash continues to be an available form of payment in stores.

claims.text: Hydrogen made from fossil fuels generates more emissions than simply burning the coal and gas for energy.

claimReview.title: Forrest’s fossil fuel hydrogen claim on the money
claimReview.textualRating: True. Multiple studies show it requires more energy and releases more emissions than burning fossil fuels.

claims.text: Voters' preferences can be misdirected by the use of the two-candidate-preferred (TCP) vote on election night.

claimReview.title: No, the AEC doesn’t misdirect voting preferences
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The TCP count is used to get an early indication of a result on the night, however all votes and preferences are counted in full in the days after.

claims.text: Drinking onion and lemon tea can help women regulate periods and delay menopause.

claimReview.title: Onion tea remedy for irregular periods is a bad brew
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence any form of tea can effect menstruation or early menopause.

claims.text: The vast majority of deaths during the Spanish flu pandemic in 1918-19 were due to bacterial infections caused by people wearing masks.

claimReview.title: Spanish flu pandemic claim masks the truth about deaths
claimReview.textualRating: False. Many people succumbed to bacterial pneumonia due to lung and immune system damage following influenza virus infection. There is no evidence mask use was the cause.

claims.text: The 2022 Australian federal election writs are bogus as the governor-general did not correctly issue them.

claimReview.title: Invalid federal election writ claim a total write-off
claimReview.textualRating: False. The writs comply with the required formatting as set out in Australian law.

claims.text: A study shows COVID-19 vaccines increase the risk of cardiac arrest in young people by 25 per cent.

claimReview.title: Emergency call study at the heart of anti-vaxx misinformation
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study’s authors and other experts say the study does not establish any causal link. They say statistical and methodological weaknesses make it hard to infer much from the results.

claims.text: The amount of carbon dioxide in the air increased just .004 per cent in 50 years.

claimReview.title: Recycled letter’s dodgy maths on C02 rise is bad for the planet
claimReview.textualRating: False. The real figure is an 11.7 per cent increase with the correct calculation.

claims.text: $35 billion in renewable energy projects have been rolled out in Australia in the past three years.

claimReview.title: Treasurer exaggerates scale of renewable energy boom
claimReview.textualRating: False. In the past three years, $24.8 billion has been invested in renewable energy projects, industry analysts say. Annual spending has been declining since 2018.

claims.text: A coalition policy enabling first-time buyers to invest up to 40 per cent of their superannuation into a home would only affect around one per cent of the housing market.

claimReview.title: PM on shaky foundations with claim about policy for first home buyers
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. First homes account for almost one-third of housing sales and theoretically each of those transactions could be affected by the policy.

claims.text: Nationals MP David Littleproud claimed $22,000 in expenses for an 84km trip between Warwick and Toowoomba in Queensland.

claimReview.title: Social media posts about MP’s travel expenses come up short
claimReview.textualRating: False. The expenses claim covered six separate trips across regional Queensland and NSW and a total travel distance of around 4000km.

claims.text: Amendments to the International Health Regulations will give the World Health Organisation power to unilaterally impose lockdowns within member countries.

claimReview.title: Claims of a WHO globalist takeover are out of this world
claimReview.textualRating: False. The amendments will not give the WHO power to override national governments on matters such as lockdowns.

claims.text: Nutella jars contain a secret knife concealed inside the lid.

claimReview.title: Nutty news spread about knives in Nutella
claimReview.textualRating: False. The viral video making the claim was created as a joke.

claims.text: Scott Morrison’s salary has risen from $140,000 to $550,000 in the past decade.

claimReview.title: Has Scott Morrison’s salary gone from $140,000 to $550,000 in a decade?
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly True. Mr Morrison earned $140,910 until March 2012, although this had increased to $231,250 by May 2012. He now receives $549,250 as prime minister.

claims.text: Thirty five major taxes including income and inheritance tax did not exist in Australia 100 years ago.

claimReview.title: Long list of Australian taxes short on sense
claimReview.textualRating: False. Several taxes in the list did exist 100 years ago and others don't apply in Australia.

claims.text: A person earning the minimum wage will pay the same rate of tax as a CEO under changes supported by the coalition and Labor.

claimReview.title: Bandt misleads with claim minimum wage earners will pay the same tax rate as CEOs
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. People earning from $45,001 to $200,000 will pay the same marginal tax rate, but those at the bottom of the bracket will have a much lower overall tax rate on their entire income.

claims.text: Radiation emitted from a mobile phone is 1000 times stronger when its battery is low.

claimReview.title: Radiation link to low phone battery lacks power
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say radiation does not increase when a phone's battery level is low.

claims.text: The coalition government did not allocate any money in the 2022/23 budget for a federal anti-corruption commission.

claimReview.title: Did the budget really include zero funding for a federal ICAC?
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The budget set aside $67 million for a federal anti-corruption body within a ‘contingency reserve’ for spending that is subject to uncertainty.

claims.text: A proposed bill will prevent Victorians growing their own food.

claimReview.title: Claim Victorians will be banned from growing food a load of crop
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Bill does not outlaw people growing their own food per se and to use it to do so would be practically and politically impossible.

claims.text: Zali Steggall's climate change bill required emissions targets to be set by an unelected commission, which could override elected officials.

claimReview.title: Near net zero truth in Wilson’s climate bill claim
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False: MPs would have set the target by voting for the bill. The minister’s decision could only be vetoed if trying to bring the target forward - a measure removed before the bill was tabled in parliament.

claims.text: The leg placement on military horse statues indicates whether the rider was injured in battle.

claimReview.title: Horse statue ‘hoof code’ doesn’t stand up
claimReview.textualRating: False. Military historians say it's an urban myth and hoof placement has no significance.

claims.text: Australia’s 2021 official death statistics provide evidence COVID-19 vaccines have caused thousands of excess deaths.

claimReview.title: Experts rubbish senator's deadly vaccine claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say the excess deaths are around a one per cent increase and can be explained by various factors including delayed health treatments during the pandemic, an ageing population and low death rates in 2020.

claims.text: The World Health Organization receives 70 per cent of its funding from the pharmaceutical industry.

claimReview.title: Big Pharma funding WHO claim is a huge furphy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The majority of the UN health agency's funding comes from member nations.

claims.text: Australia’s longest-running weather station shows no pattern of warming since temperature records were first collected in 1862.

claimReview.title: Newcastle weather station an unreliable measure for One Nation no warming claim
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. Data from the weather station in question shows a clear warming pattern since 1910 and experts say pre-1910 data from the site is unreliable.

claims.text: The phrases "dead ringer", "graveyard shift" and "saved by the bell" originate from historical attempts to prevent people being buried alive.

claimReview.title: Phrase origins linked to burials is dead wrong
claimReview.textualRating: False. The etymology of the phrases can be traced to industries with no links to burials.

claims.text: Algae ponds can capture all the carbon dioxide from coal-fired power stations, resulting in zero-emissions energy.

claimReview.title: Algae plan to make coal-fired power C02 free is not feasible
claimReview.textualRating: False. The ponds would only be able to absorb a small fraction of CO2 emitted from coal burnt at a power plant.

claims.text: The number of first-home buyers in 2021 was nearly 70,000 higher than when Labor was in government.

claimReview.title: PM cherry-picks figures in first-home buyers pitch
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. While the claim is true when comparing 2021 against Labor’s final year of office, first home loan numbers were higher under Labor when averaged across the course of governments.

claims.text: Putting sliced onion on the bottom of your feet can help to relieve a fever.

claimReview.title: Onions on feet for fever claim leaves a bad smell
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say there is no scientific evidence the remedy reduces fever.

claims.text: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson said he was pausing his country’s net zero emissions commitment.

claimReview.title: Is Boris Johnson really ‘pausing’ the UK’s net zero pledge?
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. Mr Johnson and his government have repeatedly stated support for net zero, although experts say his policies could be at odds with global efforts to limit warming.

claims.text: On any given night in Australia, more than 100,000 people do not have a roof over their head.

claimReview.title: Greens jumble numbers with claim about homelessness
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. According to the most recent census data in 2016, more than 116,000 people were technically homeless but only around 8000 people were sleeping rough.

claims.text: Welfare recipients on cashless debit cards pay a transaction fee with every purchase.

claimReview.title: No, cashless debit card users don’t get slugged with fees each purchase
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. The cards use the Visa Debit system for which transaction fees apply, but only a small proportion of these are typically passed on to users.

claims.text: The moon gives off its own light.

claimReview.title: Flat-earthers orbit in fact-free zone with lunar light theory
claimReview.textualRating: False. Light from the moon is reflected sunlight, experts say.

claims.text: The federal government’s commitment to achieve net zero emissions by 2050 is a binding target.

claimReview.title: Is Australia’s net zero emissions target actually binding?
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. Australia is unable to weaken its target under the Paris Agreement, however experts say the net zero pledge is not legally binding or enforceable.

claims.text: A "physics professor" says a mind-control weapon was used successfully in the Gulf War to force Iraqi troops to surrender.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence mind control led Iraqi troops to surrender in the Gulf War
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence such technology was used, or that it exists. In addition, the video's caption incorrectly identifies the speaker as a leading physics professor.

claims.text: Scott Morrison did not propose that asylum seeker boats should be turned back during the lead-up to the 2013 election.

claimReview.title: Labor leader rewrites history on coalition boat turnback policy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The coalition had a clear policy in support of boat turnbacks before the 2013 poll.

claims.text: Heart blockages can be cured with a do-it-yourself chest massage.

claimReview.title: Heart massage 'cure' could have serious consequences
claimReview.textualRating: False. Blocked arteries are a sign of serious disease. Chest massage has no medical benefit.

claims.text: It is more difficult and expensive to see a doctor in Australia than ever before.

claimReview.title: Labor doctors the truth on GP costs and availability
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. Official data does not support the claim it is getting harder to see a GP. While out-of-pocket costs have risen, most patients pay nothing to see a GP.

claims.text: A viral photo shows a Himalayan flower that blooms only once in 400 years.

claimReview.title: No, a Himalayan flower doesn’t bloom every 400 years
claimReview.textualRating: False. The plant, Rheum nobile, blooms once before dying. Researchers say this occurs on average after about 33 years.

claims.text: The Chinese Communist Party owns and controls some of Australia’s most popular milk brands.

claimReview.title: China milk brands ownership claim skims the facts
claimReview.textualRating: False. The majority are Australian-owned, with others being subsidiaries of Japanese or Canadian firms.

claims.text: A Labor/Greens 2011 forestry agreement caused the loss of more than 4000 jobs in Tasmania's timber industry.

claimReview.title: Liberals barking up wrong tree with Tassie timber job losses
claimReview.textualRating: False. The majority of the 4000 jobs were lost prior to the 2011 agreement with the 2008 global financial crisis a major reason.

claims.text: The Religious Discrimination Bill will make it unlawful to promote Christianity.

claimReview.title: No truth in claim proposed law would ban promotion of Christianity
claimReview.textualRating: False. The bill would protect Christian rights as well as those of other religions.

claims.text: The Australian government has given doctors permission to vaccinate people under sedation without consent.

claimReview.title: COVID vaccine without consent claim tries to sedate the truth
claimReview.textualRating: False. Vaccination under sedation is allowed in special circumstances, but consent is always required.

claims.text: The United Nations aims to reduce red meat intake to 14 grams a day per person.

claimReview.title: No, the UN hasn’t said meat intake should only be a mouthful a day
claimReview.textualRating: False. The 14-gram recommendation is from an independent report by an advocacy group. It has not been endorsed by the UN.

claims.text: No empire in history has existed for more than 250 years.

claimReview.title: Empires strike back against false 250-year claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. Many have lasted much longer than 250 years, including the Roman, Egyptian and Ottoman empires.

claims.text: New Zealand’s Digital Identity Trust Framework Bill allows government control over people’s banking.

claimReview.title: NZ bank account control claim is way off the money
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is nothing in the legislation that gives the government power over people’s bank accounts.

claims.text: The government’s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic saved 40,000 Australian lives.

claimReview.title: Did the government’s COVID-19 policies really save 40,000 Australian lives?
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. Experts say Australia’s low death rate is due to a mixture of state and federal government policy and non-government factors.

claims.text: An American Medical Association document confirms Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine ingredients and effects vary depending on their "batch".

claimReview.title: Author is crying Wolf over Pfizer vaccine batches
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim misunderstands the AMA document listing vaccine ingredient data for different age groups.

claims.text: No child under the age of two is vaccinated in Japan.

claimReview.title: Facts the best medicine for error-strewn Japanese vaccine meme
claimReview.textualRating: False. Japanese children are vaccinated from two months and the country has consistently high inoculation rates.

claims.text: An Australian government exemption certificate from 1951 reveals strict conditions placed on an Indigenous man in order to leave a reservation.

claimReview.title: Fake Indigenous exemption document has disturbing elements of truth
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. While the certificate is an advertising mock-up, experts say its contents fairly represent restrictions placed on Indigenous people at the time.

claims.text: The Morrison government cut climate spending by 35 per cent in the 2022 federal budget.

claimReview.title: Did the budget include a 35 per cent cut to climate spending?
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly True. Budget papers show a 35 per cent decline in funding for climate programs over four years, although this doesn't necessarily account for all spending by government agencies.

claims.text: Bill Gates said a cow emits more pollution than a car.

claimReview.title: No, Bill Gates never said a cow emits more pollution than a car
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence of the statement in any of his speeches and essays on climate change, and a spokeswoman denied he ever made the claim.

claims.text: A March 2022 article proves the Queensland government caused the devastating floods through cloud seeding.

claimReview.title: Seedy floods claim doesn't hold water
claimReview.textualRating: False. The article is a copy of a 2008 press release and experts say La Nina, not cloud seeding, caused the floods.

claims.text: The Australian economy is performing better than that of any other country after COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Minister overstates COVID comparison with ‘world’s best’ economy boast
claimReview.textualRating: False. Australia has had a strong recovery from the pandemic, but there are several other countries that have performed better on key indicators.

claims.text: New road rules have been imposed on Australian drivers, including bans on horn-honking and waving while behind the wheel.

claimReview.title: Reputed ‘new’ Australian road rules break down after scrutiny
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The rules cited differ from state to state, are not new and feature varying levels of accuracy.

claims.text: Fifteen tennis players withdrew or retired from the Miami Open after suffering adverse effects of the COVID-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Miami Open vaccine injury claim aced by the facts
claimReview.textualRating: False. Official tournament records cite various sports injuries and illnesses. This is supported by news reports and players' social media posts.

claims.text: Official data has confirmed 800 COVID-19 'vaccine deaths' in Australia.

claimReview.title: No, COVID vaccines have not killed 800 in Australia
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is based on a misrepresentation of vaccine safety data. Only 11 deaths have been causally linked to COVID vaccines in Australia.

claims.text: No trees have been planted toward the coalition government’s 2018 target of one billion new trees by 2030.

claimReview.title: Labor claim lays bare government failure on tree target
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly True. Around 4300 hectares of  trees have been planted since 2018, equivalent to only around one per cent of the 2030 goal.

claims.text: Three swimmers formed their own podium against US trans athlete Lia Thomas.

claimReview.title: Posts freestyle with truth about trans swimmer podium pic
claimReview.textualRating: False. The swimmers have spoken of their support for Thomas and footage shows them applauding her victory moments before the photo.

claims.text: 7000 Ukrainian troops invaded Iraq in 2003.

claimReview.title: Post misleads on Ukraine’s role in Iraq War
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The Ukraine was not part of the invading force in March 2003. In addition, the most troops the Ukraine had in Iraq at any one time was 1700.

claims.text: Australia has reduced greenhouse gas emissions by around 20 per cent - more than the US, Japan, Canada, and New Zealand.

claimReview.title: PM’s emissions cut boast rests on hazy comparison
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. Australia likely reduced net emissions by more than all except the United States between 2005 and 2020, however Australia was the worst performer when comparing gross emissions.

claims.text: The coalition government increased development aid for the Pacific region by 50 per cent.

claimReview.title: Did the Morrison government increase Pacific aid 50 per cent?
claimReview.textualRating: True. Including COVID-19 relief funding, aid to the Pacific was 56 per cent higher in 2021 than in 2013 under Labor.

claims.text: Children in Israel, Finland, Sweden and Switzerland are provided with rifles at school.

claimReview.title: Katter misfires with wild guns in school quote
claimReview.textualRating: False. None of those four countries give children firearms at school.

claims.text: The New Zealand government ignored warnings from Medsafe that there were 58 serious issues with the COVID Pfizer vaccine

claimReview.title: NZ government didn’t ignore 58 Medsafe vaccine warnings – there were none
claimReview.textualRating: False: Regulator Medsafe did not flag any serious issues with the vaccine.

claims.text: Australian government data shows fully vaccinated people account for nine out of every 10 COVID-19 deaths in the country.

claimReview.title: Truth a casualty in Australian COVID vaccination deaths claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. Australia's government does not publish COVID death figures by vaccination status. The claim misrepresents NSW data, which shows the unvaccinated are over-represented in COVID deaths.

claims.text: A scientifically controlled university study reveals humans can emit 100,000 photons of light per second by meditating.

claimReview.title: Science shines light on claims meditation makes body brighter
claimReview.textualRating: False. The university cited has distanced itself from the ‘study’ and experts say it is impossible to emit 100,000 photons per second.

claims.text: No one “said a word” in opposition to the 2003 US-led Iraq War.

claimReview.title: Iraq War post is a claim of mass deception
claimReview.textualRating: False. Historical evidence shows widespread global opposition, by governments and citizens, to the 2003 Iraq War.

claims.text: Shane Warne's son revealed his dad had chest pains from the COVID-19 vaccine prior to his death.

claimReview.title: No, Warne’s son didn’t speculate on dad’s death in online video
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video depicts far-right nationalist Blair Cottrell, not Jackson Warne. Cottrell’s claims around the cricketer’s death are unfounded.

claims.text: The coalition has only completed one, small dam project since coming to power.

claimReview.title: Labor's dam figures not quite watertight
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. Only one dam of substantial size has been completed under the coalition, however several water storage schemes involving dams have also been built with federal funding.

claims.text: There are 89 days worth of oil stock in Australia.

claimReview.title: Energy minister misleads on oil reserves in Australia
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. At the time of the claim, Australia had 64 days of oil in the country. A further 25 days of stock were in transit or overseas.

claims.text: Heart attack victims can survive by performing a series of deep coughs.

claimReview.title: No, coughing will not help you survive a heart attack
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. Cough CPR is sometimes used in a clinical setting for some patients suffering a cardiac arrest, which is different to a heart attack.

claims.text: Employers can be jailed under the “Corporate Manslaughter Act” for adverse vaccine reactions suffered by their employees.

claimReview.title: Confused vaccine manslaughter claim based on non-existent law
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no such Act and experts say such cases would not apply under existing industrial manslaughter legislation.

claims.text: In 2008, oil prices were 50 per cent higher than in 2022 but petrol was almost half the price.

claimReview.title: False 2008 oil price claim fuels petrol conspiracy
claimReview.textualRating: False. Statistics show crude oil prices in 2008 were not 50 per cent higher than this year, nor was petrol half the price.

claims.text: Root canals are toxic and scientifically proven to cause chronic illnesses.

claimReview.title: Toxic root canal claim serves up old, discredited, toothless theory
claimReview.textualRating: False. Root canal therapy takes place in a closed system and if done properly the risk of infection is minimal.

claims.text: The budget deficit and government debt are both five times higher under the coalition than they were under the previous Labor government.

claimReview.title: Rudd overshoots on scale of coalition debt and deficit
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly false. Net government debt in 2021/22 is expected to be around four times higher than when Labor left office, and the deficit about twice the size of Labor's biggest deficit.

claims.text: French President Emmanuel Macron plans to build 20 new nuclear power stations.

claimReview.title: Liberal’s French nuclear power claim melts down under scrutiny
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly false. Mr Macron has proposed building six new reactors and a prototype small modular reactor, with a further eight reactors under consideration.

claims.text: Two companies own most of the world’s largest corporations including Apple, Amazon and Coke.

claimReview.title: Global corporate monopoly claim dances on edge of reality
claimReview.textualRating: False. The companies are investment managers and don’t own the corporations.

claims.text: Ukraine is not a sovereign state and is part of Russia.

claimReview.title: Ukraine sovereignty claim ignores 30 years of independence
claimReview.textualRating: False. Ukraine declared independence in 1991 and fulfils the criteria for statehood under international law.

claims.text: Prime Minister Scott Morrison used $1 million of public money to help Clive Palmer sue Western Australia.

claimReview.title: Labor deputy misleads with Clive Palmer legal fund claim
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The $1m relates to three separate High Court cases. Mr Palmer’s WA case accounts for an unknown portion of the joint costs.

claims.text: Finland defeated Russia with a single bullet in the Winter War of 1939-40.

claimReview.title: No, Finland didn’t win the Winter War with ‘a bullet and a prayer’
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence, experts say. The war ended with signing of the Moscow Treaty where Finland ceded about 10 per cent of its territory to the Soviet Union.

claims.text: It was 'unheard of' to call in Australian Defence Force personnel following a domestic natural disaster 20 years ago.

claimReview.title: Minister needs history lesson on ADF’s disaster recovery efforts
claimReview.textualRating: False. The ADF has assisted following natural disasters in Australia throughout the period since its formation in the 1970s.

claims.text: Nurofen contains the compound, graphene oxide.

claimReview.title: Nurofen facts provide the best medicine against false ingredient claims
claimReview.textualRating: False. The black substance on Nurofen tablets is not graphene oxide but the colourant, iron oxide black, the TGA and experts confirmed.

claims.text: A university study shows that the Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine enters the nucleus of a human cell.

claimReview.title: A Swedish study did not say COVID vaccine changes human DNA
claimReview.textualRating: False. The study authors said this was not the finding of their work, which examined if mRNA from the vaccine could be changed into DNA in liver cancer cells.

claims.text: There were more than 1,200 vaccine-related deaths in the first 90 days of the Pfizer rollout.

claimReview.title: Anti-vaxxers misrepresent Pfizer report to say 1200 died in the first months of rollout
claimReview.textualRating: False: The claim that the deaths were caused by the vaccine misrepresents what the published data on adverse events actually means.

claims.text: It is a lie to say vaccines don’t cause autism.

claimReview.title: Once again: no, vaccines do not cause autism
claimReview.textualRating: False.  There is no credible evidence that vaccines cause autism.

claims.text: The coalition government has narrowed the gender pay gap.

claimReview.title: Minister’s claim about gender pay gap doesn’t pay off
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. The gender pay gap narrowed under the coalition but experts say the primary driver was workplace equality laws introduced by Labor in 2012.

claims.text: Labor cut billions of dollars from the defence budget when it was last in government.

claimReview.title: Minister off-target with claim Labor cut billions from defence
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. Labor cut defence spending in two years while in office, but overall real-term spending went up while in government.

claims.text: An image shows the first page of Shane Warne’s autobiography, describing the moment the cricketer realised he had "made it".
claims.claimant: Viral image on social media posts

claimReview.title: Viral image spins truth about Shane Warne’s autobiography
claimReview.textualRating: False. The page is a parody that a sports betting firm posted on social media in 2018.

claims.text: Cloud seeding caused record-breaking floods in Queensland and NSW.

claimReview.title: Conspiracy claims about NSW and Queensland floods fall flat
claimReview.textualRating: False. Cloud seeding is impossible on the scale of the NSW and Queensland floods. A La Nina weather system is the cause.

claims.text: Scott Morrison reduced Australia’s refugee intake by 5000.

claimReview.title: Greens leader on safe ground with claim PM cut Australia’s refugee intake
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly True. In 2020, Australia’s refugee and humanitarian visa allocation was cut from 18,750 to 13,750. The actual intake fell by more than 5000.

claims.text: Coffee is proven to cause certain types of cancer.

claimReview.title: Scientists give cancer coffee claim a roasting
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no conclusive evidence that coffee causes cancer and some studies suggest it might even protect against some cancers.

claims.text: The government can take any deposits in excess of $250,000 from your bank account and instead you can receive shares in the bank.

claimReview.title: Claim that government can grab bank deposits in a crisis has no currency
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is based on opinions that have been investigated by a parliamentary committee and found to be unsupported.

claims.text: The New Zealand High Court ruled a vaccine mandate was a gross violation of human rights.

claimReview.title: Social media claim tampers with NZ High Court ruling
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. A judge ruled the mandate unjustifiably limited some human rights of around 300 people, but he did not declare it a gross violation of human rights.

claims.text: Under the coalition government, half of the Great Barrier Reef’s coral cover has died

claimReview.title: Senator's reef damage claim ignores significant recovery
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. Half the reef’s cover died across 2016/17 but there has been significant recovery in the years since.

claims.text: The Therapeutic Goods Administration overturned a ban on ivermectin as a treatment for COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Claim TGA now backs ivermectin is a losing bet
claimReview.textualRating: False. The TGA's policy on the anti-parasitical drug to treat COVID has not changed.

claims.text: Tumours collect toxins in the body to save people's lives.

claimReview.title: 'Tumours save lives' is a cancerous claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. Tumours are cancerous cells and don't protect the body from toxins.

claims.text: Health measures pioneered in Victorian England eradicated smallpox, not the vaccine.

claimReview.title: Smallpox eradication claim denies vaccine evidence
claimReview.textualRating: False. Vaccination eradicated smallpox; health measures helped control the disease.

claims.text: The coalition government has reduced Australia’s greenhouse gas emissions by 20 per cent.
claims.claimant: Federal Resources and Water Minister Keith Pitt

claimReview.title: No minister, emissions cuts were not just the work of the coalition
claimReview.textualRating: False. Australia’s net emissions have fallen by 20.4 per cent since 2005 but the majority of the reduction happened when Labor was in power.

claims.text: Scott Morrison met with TV presenter Piers Morgan while Brisbane was under water due to flooding.

claimReview.title: No, the PM didn’t meet Piers Morgan while Brisbane was ‘under water’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The prime minister met Piers Morgan on February 24, before Brisbane had suffered major flooding.

claims.text: The coalition government has cancelled the visas of 10,000 violent criminal offenders since it came to power in 2013.

claimReview.title: Claim the government cancelled 10,000 visas of ‘violent criminals’ should be put away
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. The 10,000 figure refers to the number of visas cancelled and refused to people deemed to be of bad character, not just violent criminals. Some of those cancellations were later overturned.

claims.text: The ancient Aztecs sacrificed their leaders to the gods to avert famines and pandemics.

claimReview.title: Brutal Aztec pandemic claim sacrifices the truth
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say there is no evidence of Aztecs killing rulers to avoid such disasters.

claims.text: COVID-19 vaccines contain microscopic, self-assembling electronic components.

claimReview.title: Vaccine nanotech claim needs a check-up
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence COVID-19 vaccines contain nanotechnology.

claims.text: UK government data proves COVID-19 vaccines weaken our immune systems.

claimReview.title: Fake UK graph, ‘nonsense’ COVID vaccinated claim feature in video
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is based on a fake document; experts say there's no evidence vaccines weaken immunity.

claims.text: An Australian doctor recommended Queen Elizabeth II be treated with ivermectin for COVID-19.

claimReview.title: Queen TV story error sparks false claim about doctor’s COVID advice
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is based on a clip used in error during a TV segment on the Queen’s condition.

claims.text: There are 114 new coal and gas projects in Australia’s investment pipeline that contain more than double the amount of our annual domestic carbon emissions.

claimReview.title: New fossil fuel projects do have massive emissions potential if built
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly True. There are 114 coal and gas projects in Australia which, if completed, would produce emissions estimated to be more than double the current domestic carbon emissions of Australia. However there is uncertainty in the calculation of the potential emissions and emissions from exported fossil fuels.

claims.text: Only 83 people have died solely from COVID-19 in Australia.

claimReview.title: False COVID deaths claim sparks social media frenzy
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim misinterprets data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

claims.text: Leaking cabinet information is a criminal offence.

claimReview.title: ‘Criminal’ cabinet leak claim doesn’t hold water
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. No law specifically prohibits ministers from leaking cabinet information.

claims.text: There is no evidence carbon dioxide directly causes any change in the climate.

claimReview.title: Senator blowing hot air with climate science denial
claimReview.textualRating: False. Numerous scientific bodies and studies have found an increase in CO2 in the atmosphere has changed the climate.

claims.text: New Zealanders can make a citizen’s arrest of Health Minister Andrew Little for ‘culpable murder’ under the Crimes Act.

claimReview.title: Little chance of NZ health minister’s arrest for ‘culpable murder’
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is based on a misreading of the Crimes Act and a misunderstanding of ‘culpable murder’.

claims.text: Members of the US armed forces were jailed for 25 years for refusing the smallpox vaccine.

claimReview.title: Claim about long US jail terms for anti-vax soldiers an odd angry shot
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. There is evidence of one case, but lengthy prison terms were not widespread.

claims.text: Labor amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act in 2013 allowed schools to expel children because of their sexuality.

claimReview.title: PM’s claim Labor made it legal to expel gay students ignores important points
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading. Federal laws stopping religious schools from expelling students because of their sexuality did not exist prior to Labor's 2013 amendments and the change was supported by the coalition.

claims.text: The New Zealand government is considering putting COVID-19 vaccines into city water supplies.

claimReview.title: Truth sold down the river in post about COVID vaccine in NZ water
claimReview.textualRating: False. The story is a fabrication and the original Facebook post is a fake.

claims.text: If a person stacks the one, two, five and 10 Mexican peso coins, they form an image of the Aztec Sun Stone.
claims.claimant: Facebook group: Folklore, Customs, Legends and Mythology

claimReview.title: Aztec calendar coin claim does not stack up
claimReview.textualRating: False. Some Mexican peso coins contain stylised elements of the Aztec Sun Stone, but stacking them will not recreate it.

claims.text: More than 200 Australian doctors have been struck off the medical register during the COVID-19 pandemic.

claimReview.title: Clive Palmer’s claim 200 doctors have been ‘struck off’ fails basic check-up
claimReview.textualRating: False. Since July 2019 - before the pandemic began - 61 medical practitioners in Australia have been struck off the register for any reason.

claims.text: Cuts to Australia’s greenhouse gas emissions since 2005 are similar to those achieved in the EU.

claimReview.title: PM’s claim Australia matched EU emissions cuts doesn’t really show in the data
claimReview.textualRating: Mixture. Australia is in the middle of the pack for a selection of European countries when it comes to emissions reduction achievements but official data still shows Aussie efforts lag the EU.

claims.text: COVID-19 vaccines are not reducing hospital admission rates in NSW.

claimReview.title: NSW hospital data claim ignores vital COVID statistics
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim misinterprets data from the NSW government.

claims.text: All three major regions of the Great Barrier Reef have never had more coral on them.

claimReview.title: Great Barrier Reef ‘record coral’ claim is all at sea
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. Average coral cover reached near-historical highs in 2020-21, but none of the three major regions had record cover.

claims.text: An international court has issued arrest warrants and sentenced the Queen and other notable figures for crimes against humanity.

claimReview.title: Arrest warrants for Queen and Pope a work of legal fiction
claimReview.textualRating: False. The so-called “International Common Law Court of Justice" is meaningless and has no legal authority.

claims.text: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has net worth of $25 million.

claimReview.title: Claims about Jacinda Ardern’s wealth not worth a brass razoo
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim is not backed up by any evidence.

claims.text: Australia has recorded 12 times more deaths due to COVID-19 vaccines than from all other vaccines combined over 50 years.

claimReview.title: COVID vaccine deaths claim falls short on data coverage
claimReview.textualRating: False. The claim misrepresents vaccine adverse event reports, which do not show causality. 11 deaths have been linked to COVID-19 vaccines in Australia to date.

claims.text: An average of almost 5,000 Australians have been hospitalised with COVID-19 each day since the start of 2022.

claimReview.title: WA premier’s COVID hospitalisations claim in need of treatment
claimReview.textualRating: False. Around 3,600 people on average were in hospital with COVID-19 each day from January 1 to January 20, the date of the claim.

claims.text: A viral image shows a mountain shaped like a turtle's head in Cambodia.

claimReview.title: Truth has a mountain to climb to expose fake turtle’s head pic
claimReview.textualRating: False. The image is fabricated, combining stock images which have been manipulated.

claims.text: Americans use shorter versions of some English words because it once saved money on newspaper advertising.

claimReview.title: Americans didn’t shorten their words to save a dollar
claimReview.textualRating: False. Variant spellings of American words are attributed to lexicographer Noah Webster.

claims.text: The US Central Intelligence Agency created the term “conspiracy theorist”.

claimReview.title: Tinfoil hats not needed to repel CIA ‘conspiracy theorist’ creation claim
claimReview.textualRating: False. There's no evidence the CIA coined the term. The phrase “conspiracy theory” has been in use for least 150 years.

claims.text: Fossils on Mount Everest are evidence of global flooding.

claimReview.title: Nothing fishy about ancient marine fossils on Everest
claimReview.textualRating: False - Content that has no basis in fact.

claims.text: COVID-19 vaccination mandates are at odds with the 1986 Human Rights Commission Act

claimReview.title: COVID vaccination mandates do not contravene Australia’s human rights laws
claimReview.textualRating: False. Experts say the legislation in question does not have any relevance to vaccine mandates in Australia.

claims.text: A widely-shared Facebook post claims that a tree-sized mushroom in the United States is the world’s "largest living organism".

claimReview.title: There’s nothing magical about fake monster mushroom pic
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False – Content that has some factual inaccuracies.

claims.text: A social media post claims the United Nations’ 17 Sustainable Development Goals are part of the “New World Order” to depopulate the world and “enslave humanity”.

claimReview.title: Fake UN Sustainable Development Goals surface again
claimReview.textualRating: False - Content that has no basis in fact.

claims.text: Polling shows 75% of Australians are 'anti-vaxxers'.

claimReview.title: Online poll doesn’t have the numbers on vaccine sentiment
claimReview.textualRating: Missing context

claims.text: Eating food after 8pm is "poisonous"; skipping breakfast leads to low blood sugar levels; drinking a bottle of soft drink or beer can dramatically increase the risk of heart attack; and people shouldn't only drink water when thirsty.

claimReview.title: Some of these 12 healthy eating tips are hard to swallow
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False

claims.text: The National Party claims the proportion of electricity coming from renewable sources increased more when it was in power than under the Labour-led government, while also taking credit for that rise.

claimReview.title: National misleads with NZ renewable energy claims
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading –  The claim is accurate in parts but information has also been presented incorrectly, out of context or omitted.

claims.text: Indue, the federal government’s cashless debit card contractor, is paid $10,000 of public money per year for each card it administers.

claimReview.title: Cashless welfare card cost is way off the money
claimReview.textualRating: False. The true amount paid to Indue per card over the life of the scheme to date is estimated to be around $1200 annually.

claims.text: Facebook's app will be automatically deleted from the Google Play Store if it has a one-star rating.

claimReview.title: A one-star rating won’t get Facebook unfriended by Google
claimReview.textualRating: False

claims.text: Harold Scruby of the Pedestrian Council of Australia (PCA) claims the road toll costs Australians $30 billion each year.
claims.claimant: Harold Scruby of the Pedestrian Council of Australia

claimReview.title: Does the road toll cost Australians $30 billion per year?
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly True – Mostly accurate, but there is a minor error or problem.

claims.text: A Facebook post, shared by New Zealand users, post claims criminals are marking homes, targeting them for dog theft.

claimReview.title: Dog theft marker or myth? What a “pet tag” around a fence means
claimReview.textualRating: False - The primary claims of the content are factually inaccurate or misleading.

claims.text: A Facebook post makes several false or misleading claims about United States president-elect Joe Biden and corruption linked to Ukraine.

claimReview.title: No, Joe Biden hasn’t been tied to ‘huge corruption’ in Ukraine
claimReview.textualRating: False – Content that has no basis in fact.

claims.text: Plant-based meats contain chemicals including titanium dioxide, methylcellulose, propylene glycol, ferric phosphate and magnesium carbonate, which are used in various toxic products.

claimReview.title: Are plant-based ‘meats’ just another person’s poison?
claimReview.textualRating: Missing Context - The post may mislead without additional context.

claims.text: Government Services Minister Stuart Robert claims no debt recovery notices had been issued in the flood-affected north Queensland city of Townsville.
claims.claimant: Federal Government Services Minister Stuart Robert.

claimReview.title: Have debt recovery notices been issued in flood-affected Townsville despite federal government assurances they haven’t?
claimReview.textualRating: Ambiguous - It is not possible to determine the veracity of the statement.

claims.text: A social media post claims passenger cruise ships are booked to return to Tasmania as early as December 2020.

claimReview.title: Is Tasmania about to welcome back cruise ships?
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False - Content that has some factual inaccuracies.

claims.text: Children as young as 10 have been fined for not wearing face masks in Victoria.

claimReview.title: No, 10-year-olds aren’t being fined for going maskless in Victoria
claimReview.textualRating: False. Official data shows Victoria Police has not issued face mask fines to any children younger than 13.

claims.text: A Facebook post claims that "a new vaccine for COVID-19" will alter a person’s DNA and genetically modify humans.

claimReview.title: Vaccine being developed for COVID-19 won’t alter a person’s DNA
claimReview.textualRating: False - The claims in the post are factually inaccurate.

claims.text: COVID-19 vaccines cause antibody dependent enhancement (ADE), which can lead to serious illness when people are exposed to the virus.
claims.claimant: Facebook users in Papua New Guinea

claimReview.title: Vaccines don’t make people sicker if they get COVID
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence of ADE from COVID-19 vaccines, which have repeatedly been shown to reduce hospitalisation and serious illness.

claims.text: Nikola Tesla said: "Death does not exist, and with that very knowledge, the fear of it disappears. And remember: no man who existed died. They turned into light and as such still exist."

claimReview.title: Nikola Tesla’s ‘death and light’ quote dims under closer scrutiny
claimReview.textualRating: False – Content that has no basis in fact.

claims.text: National leader Judith Collins claims that 30 per cent of COVID-19 tests returned a false negative result in the context of New Zealand's managed isolation testing.

claimReview.title: Just how effective are COVID-19 tests conducted in NZ’s managed isolation?
claimReview.textualRating: Misleading - The claim is accurate in parts but information has also been presented incorrectly, out of context or omitted.

claims.text: Sky News host Rowan Dean claims that a graph shows temperatures haven't risen in more than two decades.

claimReview.title: Has there really been no warming of the planet in 22 years?
claimReview.textualRating: False – The checkable claim is false.

claims.text: Dietary salt does not cause water retention, high blood pressure or kidney damage.

claimReview.title: Sodium ‘myths’ to be taken with a grain of salt
claimReview.textualRating: False

claims.text: A Facebook post claims that women used to apologise to their husbands at Christmas for their mistakes and ask for forgiveness in an apparently forgotten tradition.

claimReview.title: Tall tale of women begging for forgiveness is a Christmas cracker
claimReview.textualRating: False – Content that has no basis in fact.

claims.text: New Zealand First leader Winston Peters claims that government spending on superannuation is 4.4 per cent of GDP, and its commitment is low by international standards.
claims.claimant: New Zealand First leader Winston Peters

claimReview.title: Does NZ spend less on pensions than most wealthy countries?
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly True - The claim is mostly accurate but there is a minor error or problem.

claims.text: NZ National Party drug reform spokesman Nick Smith claims random roadside alcohol testing halved drunk driving fatalities in three years.
claims.claimant: Nick Smith, NZ National Party drug reform spokesman

claimReview.title: Drink driving fatalities were halved by RBT in NZ, but it took more than three years
claimReview.textualRating: Somewhat False – The claim has a problem or inaccuracy but it does contain a significant element or elements of truth.

claims.text: Spike proteins from COVID-19 mRNA vaccines often cause permanent damage to children’s vital organs.

claimReview.title: Child vaccination video fails screen test for truth
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence vaccine spike proteins cause any common and serious side effects.

claims.text: An Instagram post claims that a new Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) report "shows that 94% of COVID-19 deaths in the US had underlying medical conditions".

claimReview.title: Claims on CDC data for COVID-19 incorrect, say experts
claimReview.textualRating: False - The primary claims within the post are inaccurate.

claims.text: Did visiting UK activist Raheem Kassam described the Koran as ‘fundamentally evil’ and Islam as a ‘fascistic ideology”?
claims.claimant: Labor's Home Affairs spokesperson, Kristina Keneally

claimReview.title: Did UK activist Raheem Kassam describe the Koran as ‘fundamentally evil’ and Islam as a ‘fascistic ideology?
claimReview.textualRating: True - The checkable claims are all true.

claims.text: A Facebook post claims that an eruption from Italian volcano Mount Etna has created more greenhouse gas emissions than all mankind throughout history.
claims.claimant: Facebook page, The Greens Little Bag of Stupidity

claimReview.title: No carbon contest between emissions-heavy humans and volcanoes
claimReview.textualRating: False

claims.text: Italy is highlighted in a social media post to emphasise the importance of staying home during coronavirus by using a photo of multiple coffins to reinforce the message.

claimReview.title: Italy’s COVID-19 situation is dire but a photo of coffins is not from the coronavirus pandemic
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False - The claims of the content are a mixture of accurate and inaccurate or the primary claim is misleading or incomplete.

claims.text: Comorbidity data from an Australian Department of Health report shows there are far fewer coronavirus-related deaths than those reported in official figures.

claimReview.title: Post misleads on Australian COVID-19 death data
claimReview.textualRating: False – The primary claims within the post are inaccurate.

claims.text: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has claimed that coal from rival exporters produces 50 per cent more emissions than Australia's product.

claimReview.title: PM’s claim Australian coal produces much lower emissions is ‘nonsense’
claimReview.textualRating: False – The checkable claim is false.

claims.text: A Facebook post purports to show canned animal brains were sold by Heinz in Australia in the 1980s.

claimReview.title: The offal truth about “canned in Australia” brains
claimReview.textualRating: False - The primary claims of the content are factually inaccurate.

claims.text: Federal Energy Minister Angus Taylor claims AGL, Origin Energy and EnergyAustralia - often referred to as the big three of electricity retailers - are experiencing record profits as their customers struggle to pay their bills. Mr Taylor wants greater protections for electricity consumers.

claimReview.title: Are big energy companies enjoying a run of record profits as customers struggle to pay power bills?
claimReview.textualRating: Somewhat False - Mostly false, but there is more than one element of truth.

claims.text: A viral photo and video show 2021 anti-government protests in Cuba.

claimReview.title: ‘Cuban protests’ imagery is close but no cigar
claimReview.textualRating: False

claims.text: Sweden has a speed camera lottery in which drivers who obey the speed limit can win prizes drawn from fines issued to speeding drivers.

claimReview.title: Sweden’s ‘speed camera lottery’ hit a red light years ago
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False

claims.text: AstraZeneca means "to kill the stars" in Latin.

claimReview.title: AstraZeneca Latin 'meaning' loses something in translation
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False – Content that has some factual inaccuracies.

claims.text: Eighty per cent of pregnant women in NZ who have been vaccinated for COVID-19 experience miscarriages.

claimReview.title: No, most vaccinated pregnant women in NZ haven’t miscarried
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no evidence of increased rates of miscarriage among vaccinated pregnant women in NZ or elsewhere.

claims.text: Paul Goldsmith, National Party finance spokesperson, claims that New Zealanders earning between $50,000 and $70,000 would be $3000 better off under National’s proposed tax cuts.
claims.claimant: Paul Goldsmith, National Party finance spokesperson

claimReview.title: National overstates benefit of NZ tax cut plan
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False - The claim is mostly false with one minor element of truth.

claims.text: An image of a creature with a row of small, pointed teeth shows an earthworm under a microscope.

claimReview.title: Lots of wriggle room in truth about viral ‘earthworm’ image
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly false. The image actually shows a deep ocean scale worm, not an earthworm. The two invertebrates bear little resemblance under a microscope.

claims.text: ABC journalist Laura Tingle said Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison's staff were "hiring lawyers to protect themselves from him".

claimReview.title: Veteran journalist verballed in quote about PM staff ‘lawyering up’
claimReview.textualRating: False

claims.text: New Zealand's greenhouse gas emissions have increased, while Australia's have decreased.

claimReview.title: Has Australia cut its greenhouse emissions faster than New Zealand?
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False – The claim is mostly false with one minor element of truth.

claims.text: A Facebook post claims to bear a message from Clint Eastwood as he starts "preparing to say goodbye", in which the Hollywood star purportedly blasts Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden.

claimReview.title: No, Clint Eastwood didn’t mark his ‘twilight years’ with a Biden attack
claimReview.textualRating: False – Content that has no basis in fact.

claims.text: A post criticises the composition of the body advising the Australian government on economic recovery from COVID-19, saying the members of the organisation do not have medical qualifications.

claimReview.title: Misleading claim about COVID Commission ignores why the advisory body was set up
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False - The primary claim is misleading or incomplete.

claims.text: Anthony Field of Australian children's music group The Wiggles has died.

claimReview.title: Red flag raised over false claim of blue Wiggle’s death
claimReview.textualRating: False. Anthony Field is still alive.

claims.text: A post claims that methane emitted by cattle is absorbed by plants in a natural cycle that does not increase greenhouse gas emissions.

claimReview.title: Claim that cow-caused methane doesn’t raise emissions is just hot air
claimReview.textualRating: False - The primary claims of the content are factually incorrect.

claims.text: Claim that COVID-19 is "fake" and that the pandemic is cover for the installation of 5G telecommunications towers.

claimReview.title: False claims about COVID-19, 5G and a vaccine that doesn’t exist yet
claimReview.textualRating: False - The primary claims of the content are factually inaccurate or misleading.  AAP FactCheck found the claims of the post to be false. COVID-19 is not "fake" but is a highly infectious viral disease caused by a newly discovered coronavirus. Claims of a link between COVID-19 and 5G telecommunications ignore expert medical research and advice, and the fact that COVID-19 is present in many nations without 5G networks. The claim that the vaccine for COVID-19 contains an RFID chip is a fabrication as a vaccine does not exist.

claims.text: In 2019, Labor had a policy to raise the price of petrol to force people to switch to electric vehicles.

claimReview.title: PM’s claim about Labor’s 2019 electric car policy is all gas
claimReview.textualRating: False. Labor had no such stated policy, and any link between the opposition's then proposals and increased fuel prices was only tangential.

claims.text: Charlie Chaplin said the "six best doctors in the world" include sun, rest and exercise. Several other quotes are also attributed to the actor-director in the same viral posts.

claimReview.title: Did Charlie Chaplin say the ‘world’s best doctors’ include sun, rest and exercise?
claimReview.textualRating: Partly False – Content that has some factual inaccuracies.

claims.text: A Facebook post claims a Melbourne factory is sending food, toilet paper and other items to China.

claimReview.title: False claims of goods being shipped to China damage Melbourne companies
claimReview.textualRating: False – The primary claims of the content are false.

claims.text: It is illegal for a front-seat passenger to use a mobile phone in a moving vehicle in Queensland.

claimReview.title: Queensland hasn’t curbed car passengers using mobile phones
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly False. There is no law preventing passengers from using mobiles, although the driver can be fined if the screen is visible to them.

claims.text: Australia suspended its entire COVID-19 vaccination program because it made people seriously ill, caused deaths and made recipients HIV-positive.

claimReview.title: Infowars video on Australia’s COVID vaccine program misfires

claims.text: ACT Party leader David Seymour claims that New Zealand's $6 billion surplus had been reduced to a $1 billion deficit in the space of two years pre-COVID-19.
